meta.disclaimer: Seed questions are MAP-style practice questions from TestPrep-Online. Expanded questions are AI-generated following the same format and difficulty calibration. NOT official NWEA questions.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Jane has 6 flowers. She planted 3 more flowers. How many flowers does Jane have now?
questions.explanation: Jane started with 6 flowers and planted 3 more. 6 + 3 = 9 flowers total.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Identify the three-dimensional shape shown in the image.
questions.explanation: The shape shown is a cylinder — it has two circular bases and a curved surface connecting them.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: According to the bar graph, which food was chosen by the fewest students?
questions.explanation: Reading the bar graph, hamburger has the shortest bar, meaning the fewest students chose it.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: 5 + ___ = 12. What is the missing number?
questions.explanation: To find the missing number: 12 - 5 = 7. So 5 + 7 = 12.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, ___. What is the next number?
questions.explanation: The pattern increases by 2 each time: 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What is the name of your teacher. Which punctuation mark should go at the end of this sentence?
questions.explanation: This is a question (it asks for information), so it needs a question mark (?).

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which pair of words are synonyms (have the same meaning)?
questions.explanation: Afraid and Scared both mean feeling fear. The other pairs have different meanings.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What is the plural form of 'mouse'?
questions.explanation: Mouse is an irregular noun. Its plural form is 'mice', not 'mouses'.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What does 'tallest' mean?
questions.explanation: The suffix '-est' means the most. 'Tallest' means the most tall of all.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What type of text is shown?
questions.explanation: The text shows items arranged in a vertical format with bullet points or numbers, which is the format of a list.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which of the following represents the multiplication 2 × 4?

options.label: A
options.text: Image showing apples in two groups (4 and 2)

options.label: B
options.text: Image showing two groups of 3 books each

options.label: C
options.text: Image showing two groups of 2 glasses each

options.label: D
options.text: Image showing 2 bunches of 4 bananas each

questions.explanation: 2 × 4 means 2 groups with 4 items each. Only option D shows this correctly with 2 bunches of 4 bananas.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A farm has a total of 23 animals. There are as many cows as the tens digit in the total number of animals on the farm. There are as many pigs as the ones digit in total number of animals on the farm. The rest of the animals are sheep. What is the correct distribution of animals in the farm?

options.label: A
options.text: Three cows, two pigs, and 18 sheep

options.label: B
options.text: Three cows, two pigs, and 23 sheep

options.label: C
options.text: Two cows, three pigs, and 18 sheep

options.label: D
options.text: Two cows, three pigs, and 23 sheep

questions.explanation: The number 23 has tens digit 2 and ones digit 3, meaning 2 cows and 3 pigs. 23 - 2 - 3 = 18 sheep.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which of the following shapes has been divided into equal parts?

options.label: A
options.text: Triangle divided into three smaller triangles

options.label: C
options.text: Trapezoid divided into three different-sized triangles

questions.explanation: Both the triangle (three identical triangular pieces) and the circle (four equal quarter-sections) show shapes divided into congruent sections.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: How many books were read in the month of August? (Based on bar graph)
questions.explanation: Reading the bar graph, the August bar reaches the 400 mark on the vertical axis.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: How was Lindsay and Gretchen's problem resolved? (Story about twins wanting different pets)

options.label: A
options.text: One received her preferred pet; the other was disappointed

options.label: B
options.text: Pet store employee helped them decide

options.label: C
options.text: They decided on a pet together

questions.explanation: The narrative states they worked out their differences and decided together which pet to take, selecting a rabbit they both agreed upon.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What type of text is this? (referring to the twins and pet story)
questions.explanation: The narrative teaches the lesson of compromise and cooperation, demonstrating characteristics of literature with a moral message.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Based on the index, in which of the following pages would you find a Roald Dahl story? (Dahl listed as pages 99–124)
questions.explanation: Only page 102 falls within the 99–124 range designated for Roald Dahl content.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Click on two types of information you are likely to find in a newspaper.

options.label: C
options.text: Directions for how to get to places

questions.explanation: Newspapers primarily contain current events reporting and commercial advertisements.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: The friendly neighbors live two floors above our apartment. Which set of words all mean the opposite of the preposition 'above'?
questions.explanation: All three words in option C (beneath, under, below) denote position lower than something, making them true opposites of 'above'.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Click on the contraction in which the apostrophe is in the right place.
questions.explanation: The apostrophe in 'couldn't' correctly replaces the omitted 'o' from 'not', following proper contraction rules.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Darling, please go to the pantry and grab a few ________ for me. Which words complete the sentence correctly?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'a few' requires plural forms for both the container and contents: 'cans of beans'.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which version moves the word 'darling' to the most suitable spot in the sentence: 'Darling, please go to the pantry and grab a few ________ for me.'

options.label: A
options.text: Please go to the pantry, darling, and grab a few ________ for me

options.label: B
options.text: Please go, darling, to the pantry and grab a few ________ for me

options.label: C
options.text: Please go to the pantry and grab, darling, a few ________ for me

questions.explanation: Placing 'darling' between two complete clauses maintains natural sentence flow without interrupting individual thoughts.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Suppose you are asked to write a school essay titled 'Why I Like Going to the Museum.' Which details support the topic of the essay? (Select two)

options.label: A
options.text: At the museum, you can learn about interesting things

options.label: B
options.text: The museum has a gift shop with cool T-shirts

options.label: C
options.text: Walking from hall to hall in the museum can be tiring

options.label: D
options.text: You must remember to keep quiet at the museum

options.label: E
options.text: Some museum exhibits can be boring

questions.explanation: Only options containing positive language ('interesting', 'cool') support an essay about enjoying museum visits.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which number is missing from this sequence? 750, 725, 700, ___, 625
questions.explanation: The pattern decreases by 25 each time: 750, 725, 700, 675, 650. The missing number is 675.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Mary needs eggs for cake dough. How many eggs does she need?
questions.explanation: Based on the recipe proportions, Mary needs 18 eggs.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which picture shows 1/3 of a region shaded?
questions.explanation: 1/3 means the shape is divided into 3 equal parts and 1 part is shaded.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the perimeter of a rectangle that is 7 inches long and 3 inches wide?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 2 × (length + width) = 2 × (7 + 3) = 2 × 10 = 20 inches.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which title best fits a passage about a sailor who endures a storm and completes his journey?
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the complete journey including overcoming the storm, making 'A Successful Journey' the most comprehensive title.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: A passage describes four animals with camouflage abilities. What common trait do they share?
questions.explanation: The common trait described across all four animals is their ability to camouflage or mask themselves.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: In the sentence 'She enjoys the company of her friends', what does 'company' mean?

options.label: B
options.text: The person or people who are with you

questions.explanation: In this context, 'company' means the people who are with you — her friends.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which word is a correctly spelled plural noun?
questions.explanation: Teeth is the correct irregular plural of tooth. The others should be children, geese, and mice.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Complete the sentence: 'The race had already _______ by the time we arrived.'
questions.explanation: After 'had' (past perfect), use the past participle 'begun'.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which sentence has correct word order?
questions.explanation: In standard English, adverbs of manner typically come after the verb: 'The dog ran quickly.'

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which sentence best concludes a paragraph about endangered Javan rhinoceros?

options.label: A
options.text: There are many animals in the zoo.

options.label: C
options.text: We must act now to protect the Javan rhinoceros before it is too late.

questions.explanation: A concluding sentence should summarize the main idea and provide a call to action related to the topic — protecting the endangered species.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A supermarket packed 60 eggs into four egg boxes, split equally. How many eggs were in three boxes?
questions.explanation: 60 ÷ 4 = 15 eggs per box. 15 × 3 = 45 eggs in three boxes.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A number pattern starts with 12 and ends with 39. Which rule is suitable?
questions.explanation: 39 - 12 = 27. 27 ÷ 9 = 3 steps. Pattern: 12, 21, 30, 39. Skip counting by 9s works.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which triangle is isosceles based on its angle measurements?
questions.explanation: An isosceles triangle has exactly two equal angles. Option B has two 72° angles.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which item weighs approximately a gram?
questions.explanation: A gram is very light — about the weight of a paper clip. Only a stick of gum approaches this weight.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What is the theme of Joyce Kilmer's poem 'Trees'?
questions.explanation: The poem celebrates and praises the beauty of trees and nature.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: A passage about Antarctica mentions its size compared to Europe and Australia. Why does the author mention these continents?

options.label: A
options.text: To show how big Antarctica is

questions.explanation: The author uses familiar continents as reference points to help readers understand Antarctica's enormous size.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: In the word 'unemployed', what does the prefix 'un-' mean?
questions.explanation: The prefix 'un-' means 'not'. Unemployed = not employed.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: What is the correct spelling for more than one wolf?
questions.explanation: Words ending in 'f' change to 'ves' in plural form: wolf → wolves.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: What is the definition of a proper noun?

options.label: A
options.text: A word that describes an action

options.label: B
options.text: A word that describes another word

options.label: C
options.text: A general word for a person, place, or thing

options.label: D
options.text: A word that names a particular person, place, or thing

questions.explanation: A proper noun names a specific, particular person, place, or thing and is always capitalized.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: In the sentence 'Ethan almost left his white socks at the gym', what is the subject?
questions.explanation: The subject is the person performing the action. Ethan is the one who almost left his socks.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: What is required in research writing?
questions.explanation: Research writing requires citing sources and providing a list of references to support the information presented.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which decimal is represented by the shaded region of a 10×10 grid?
questions.explanation: Count the shaded squares in the 10×10 grid: 28 out of 100 = 0.28.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is 7/8 − 1/6?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Find the missing angle in a triangle with two known angles of 25° and 42°.
questions.explanation: Sum of angles in a triangle = 180°. Missing angle = 180° − 25° − 42° = 113°.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Select all measurements equal to six hours.
questions.explanation: 6 hours = 6 × 60 = 360 minutes. 6 hours = 6 × 3600 = 21,600 seconds.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What point of view is used in the excerpt from Anne of Green Gables?
questions.explanation: The narrator refers to characters by name (he/she) and has access to multiple characters' thoughts — this is third person omniscient.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: A passage about the Galápagos Islands states several facts. What does the passage NOT state?

options.label: D
options.text: It is a popular tourist destination

questions.explanation: The passage describes the islands' geology, Darwin's visit, and wildlife, but does not mention tourism.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What is the closest meaning to 'fallacy'?
questions.explanation: A fallacy is a mistaken belief or misconception — something that appears true but is actually false.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses commas with direct address?

options.label: A
options.text: Thank you Manuel for your help yesterday.

options.label: B
options.text: Thank you, Manuel for your help yesterday.

options.label: C
options.text: Thank you Manuel, for your help yesterday.

options.label: D
options.text: Thank you, Manuel, for your help yesterday.

questions.explanation: Names used in direct address must be set off by commas on both sides when they appear in the middle of a sentence.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which word is the active verb in the sentence?
questions.explanation: 'Visited' is the active verb — it shows the subject performing an action. The others can function as adjectives or passive participles.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which of the following is a compound sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: The cat sat on the mat and purred.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it rained, we stayed inside.

options.label: C
options.text: It was hot yesterday, so I wore short pants and a t-shirt.

options.label: D
options.text: Running through the park, she tripped.

questions.explanation: A compound sentence has two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction. 'It was hot yesterday' and 'I wore short pants and a t-shirt' are both independent clauses joined by 'so'.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: A passage uses signal words like 'start by', 'then', 'once'. What organizational pattern is this?
questions.explanation: Words like 'start by', 'then', and 'once' indicate sequential steps — a sequence organizational pattern.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which is the best decomposition to simplify the multiplication 382 × 17?
questions.explanation: Breaking 382 into 300 + 80 + 2, then multiplying each by 17 uses place value to simplify the calculation.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which line plot correctly represents the swimming time data from a given table?
questions.explanation: Plot B correctly shows the frequency distribution across fractional values matching the data table.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The perimeter of a rectangle is 32. The width is 7. What is the area?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 2(l + w) → 32 = 2(l + 7) → l = 9. Area = l × w = 9 × 7 = 63.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: A passage describes sweet potatoes and their characteristics. Why did the author write this passage?
questions.explanation: The passage presents factual information about sweet potatoes, indicating the author's purpose is to inform.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: In a storm scene with children in an attic, what does the phrase 'deafeningly silent' accomplish?
questions.explanation: 'Deafeningly silent' is an oxymoron — combining contradictory words creates a dramatic, tense effect.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Jane moved gingerly through the dangerous forest. What does 'gingerly' mean?
questions.explanation: Context clues ('dangerous forest') suggest Jane was moving carefully. 'Gingerly' means with extreme caution.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which sentence correctly punctuates a split quotation?

options.label: A
options.text: "Students" Mr. Hernandez instructed "please bring your history books tomorrow."

options.label: B
options.text: "Students," Mr. Hernandez instructed, "Please bring your history books tomorrow."

options.label: C
options.text: "Students," Mr. Hernandez instructed, "please bring your history books tomorrow."

options.label: D
options.text: "Students", Mr. Hernandez instructed, "please bring your history books tomorrow."

questions.explanation: In a split quotation, the second part uses lowercase unless it starts a new sentence. Commas go inside quotation marks.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which sentence uses pronouns correctly?

options.label: A
options.text: My parents ask my sister and I to help with chores.

options.label: B
options.text: My parents ask I and my sister to help with chores.

options.label: C
options.text: My parents ask my sister and me to help with chores.

options.label: D
options.text: My parents ask me and my sister to help with chores.

questions.explanation: Object pronouns ('me') follow verbs that direct action toward them. 'My sister and me' is the correct object form.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which underlined portion is an independent clause?
questions.explanation: 'The ship stayed on course' has a subject and verb and expresses a complete thought — it's an independent clause.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: What is the best topic sentence for a paragraph about dog care?

options.label: A
options.text: Dogs are the most popular pets in the world.

options.label: B
options.text: Dog care requires both a daily routine and checkups with a veterinarian.

options.label: C
options.text: My dog likes to play fetch in the park.

options.label: D
options.text: There are many breeds of dogs.

questions.explanation: A good topic sentence introduces the main idea broadly enough to support the paragraph's details about dog care.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: An ice cream shop uses 4 liters of ice cream to make 16 cones. If the shop plans to sell 80 cones and expects to lose 0.25 liters of ice cream to melting/waste for each batch of 16 cones, how many liters should they buy in total?
questions.explanation: Batches needed: 80 ÷ 16 = 5. Ice cream: 4 × 5 = 20L. Waste: 0.25 × 5 = 1.25L. Total: 20 + 1.25 = 21.25L.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the correct order for the time measurements from smallest to largest? 1/6 of a day, 3.5 hours, 250 minutes, 6000 seconds

options.label: A
options.text: 1/6 of a day, 3.5 hours, 250 minutes, 6000 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 6000 seconds, 3.5 hours, 250 minutes, 1/6 of a day

options.label: C
options.text: 6000 seconds, 3.5 hours, 1/6 of a day, 250 minutes

options.label: D
options.text: 250 minutes, 6000 seconds, 3.5 hours, 1/6 of a day

questions.explanation: Convert to minutes: 6000s = 100min, 3.5h = 210min, 1/6 day = 240min, 250min = 250min. Order: 100 < 210 < 240 < 250.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which pairs of triangles are similar?
questions.explanation: Pair (a) demonstrates SAS similarity; Pair (b) demonstrates SSS similarity; Pair (c) lacks matching angles and side information.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Use the graph to answer: What is the unit rate per crate? (Graph shows time vs. number of crates picked)
questions.explanation: Reading the graph at x=1 crate shows y=3 minutes, establishing the unit rate of 3 minutes per crate.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Robert Frost's 'The Road Not Taken' is a narrative poem because it _______
questions.explanation: A narrative poem specifically tells a story with characters, events, setting, and sequence.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What is the attitude of the speaker in 'The Road Not Taken'?
questions.explanation: The speaker demonstrates deep reflection through phrases like 'long I stood' and 'I doubted', showing thoughtful consideration.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What is one logical reason, according to the passage, for the knocker-uppers to knock on the windows instead of the doors of the customers?

options.label: A
options.text: They thought it was an easier way to wake people up

options.label: B
options.text: They decided knocking on doors was too old-fashioned

options.label: C
options.text: They wanted to wake up only the customers

options.label: D
options.text: They thought it made the job seem more desirable

questions.explanation: The passage states they knocked 'loudly enough to wake up the people inside the house, but softly enough not to wake the neighbors' — selective awakening of paying customers.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What is the meaning of the Greek root 'phil'?
questions.explanation: The root 'phil' means love/affection, as in bibliophile (book lover) and philharmonic (music lover).

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: She said, '_____ live in North Carolina now, but we used to live in _____ Europe.' Which words correctly fill the blanks?
questions.explanation: First word of a quotation requires capital 'W'. 'western' is a descriptive adjective (not part of an official name), so it stays lowercase.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: A molecule is approximately one million times smaller than a grain of sand. Which word is modified by the adjective 'smaller'?
questions.explanation: The adjective 'smaller' describes the subject 'molecule'. Ask: 'What is smaller?' — the molecule.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which underlined section of a passage about Ada Lovelace is an independent clause?

options.label: A
options.text: the daughter of the famous poet Lord Byron

options.label: C
options.text: proposing that computers could perform many tasks besides calculations

options.label: D
options.text: Though Lovelace didn't live long enough to see her ideas put into practice

questions.explanation: 'She met Charles Babbage' has a subject ('she') and conjugated verb ('met'), expressing a complete thought.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which is the best thesis for a persuasive essay on the first time people landed on the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: The moon landing is an event known by everyone in the US

options.label: B
options.text: The moon landing was part of NASA's Apollo program

options.label: C
options.text: The moon landing is an achievement that humanity would have certainly reached at some point in one way or another

options.label: D
options.text: A famous sentence said by Neil Armstrong during the landing was, 'That's one small step for a man...'

questions.explanation: A persuasive thesis presents an arguable claim. Option C presents a debatable assertion suitable for persuasive development.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the value of angle α in a triangle where one exterior angle measures 145° and an adjacent interior angle is 60°?
questions.explanation: By the Exterior Angle Theorem, the exterior angle equals the sum of the two remote interior angles: 60° + α = 145°, so α = 85°.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A school choir has 84 students. The ratio of boys to girls is 3:4. After auditions, 12 new girls join and 6 boys leave. What is the new ratio of girls to boys?
questions.explanation: Original: 36 boys, 48 girls. After changes: 30 boys, 60 girls. New ratio: 60:30 = 2:1.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Solve for y: 2y/3 + 17 = −51
questions.explanation: Subtract 17: 2y/3 = −68. Multiply by 3/2: y = −102.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A baseball cap contains 9 baseballs: 4 blue, 3 white, 2 orange. A player selects 3 one at a time without replacement. What is the probability that none are blue?

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which sentence uses figurative language to convey an abstract idea? (Passage about 'Powers of Ten' film)

options.label: A
options.text: The camera steadily zooms outward, expanding the view by a power of ten each interval.

options.label: B
options.text: Trying to grasp these extremes feels like trying to hold the ocean in a teacup.

options.label: C
options.text: The film reverses direction and explores the microscopic world of cells and proteins.

options.label: D
options.text: The distances in the universe stretch the limits of human imagination.

questions.explanation: Option B uses a simile comparing conceptual difficulty to an impossible physical task, expressing an abstract idea through vivid comparison.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which technique does the author use most effectively to help readers understand the extreme nature of fleas' abilities?

options.label: A
options.text: Emphasizing scientific terminology to highlight biological precision

options.label: B
options.text: Presenting direct factual descriptions of the flea's anatomy and daily behavior

options.label: C
options.text: Framing flea abilities through large-scale numerical and conceptual comparisons

options.label: D
options.text: Using vivid adjectives to portray fleas as remarkable and unusual creatures

questions.explanation: The author repeatedly translates flea abilities into human-scale comparisons (e.g., 'a jump would launch a person high enough to clear a skyscraper').

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Determine the definition of 'cajole' based on context: (1) politician cajoled voters with tax reduction promises; (2) friend cajoled her into attending event.

options.label: A
options.text: To compel someone into action by creating urgency

options.label: B
options.text: To persuade someone by sustained coaxing or flattery

options.label: C
options.text: To subtly manipulate outcomes without direct interaction

options.label: D
options.text: To engage in negotiation involving concessions

questions.explanation: Context shows gentle, personal persuasion through repeated urging and attractive promises — 'cajole' means to persuade by coaxing or flattery.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which statement is true about Emily Dickinson's poem 'I'm nobody! Who are you?'

options.label: A
options.text: The poem maintains a consistent rhyme scheme.

options.label: B
options.text: The poem maintains a consistent pattern of meter.

options.label: C
options.text: Each line of the poem is in tetrameter form.

questions.explanation: The poem follows alternating long/short line patterns throughout, demonstrating consistent meter despite varying rhyme density.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: What is the function of the final sentence: 'Even so, interest in the deep ocean continues to grow as researchers learn more about its potential value'?

options.label: A
options.text: It reinforces the earlier idea that the deep ocean holds important resources.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides evidence that challenges the claim made in the first sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: It explains why deep-sea exploration has become less common in recent years.

options.label: D
options.text: It contrasts the growing interest with the difficulties mentioned earlier.

questions.explanation: 'Even so' signals contrast between previously mentioned obstacles and continuing increased interest.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which revision best improves clarity and removes ambiguity from: 'Because the committee wanted community members to share their opinions in as many ways as possible, they allowed an online form, individual interviews, and a suggestion box, which made the results more confusing than expected.'

options.label: A
options.text: Seeking extensive public input, the committee implemented multiple feedback methods...which ultimately produced data that was difficult to interpret.

options.label: B
options.text: To gather community opinions through varied channels, the committee offered several participation options; however, these methods collectively generated results that were unexpectedly complex to analyze.

options.label: C
options.text: Wanting a wide range of perspectives, the committee provided an online form, individual interviews, and a suggestion box, although the combination...

options.label: D
options.text: To encourage contributions through multiple avenues, the committee adopted an online form...

questions.explanation: Option B eliminates pronoun ambiguity by naming 'committee' directly and clarifies cause-effect with 'collectively generated results'.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Combine three statements about the Hubble Space Telescope: (1) launched 1990; (2) instrumental in major discoveries; (3) orbits Earth at 340 miles.

options.label: A
options.text: Launched in 1990 and instrumental in many major discoveries, the Hubble Space Telescope orbits Earth at approximately 340 miles above the surface.

options.label: B
options.text: Orbiting Earth at 340 miles above the surface, the Hubble Space Telescope was launched in 1990, and it has been instrumental...

options.label: C
options.text: The Hubble Space Telescope, a device instrumental in numerous major astronomical discoveries, was launched in 1990 and orbits Earth at approximately 340 miles above the surface.

options.label: D
options.text: Instrumental in numerous major astronomical discoveries and orbiting Earth, the Hubble Space Telescope was launched in 1990...

questions.explanation: Option C uses an appositive phrase to integrate the discoveries fact smoothly while presenting launch date and orbital information in balanced parallel structure.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Select the sentence using correct pronoun-antecedent agreement and maintaining grammatical parallelism.

options.label: A
options.text: Every student must submit their project proposal and be sure they proofread carefully.

options.label: B
options.text: Each student must submit their project proposal and ensure they proofreads carefully.

options.label: C
options.text: Every student must submit his or her project proposal and ensure that it is proofread carefully.

options.label: D
options.text: Each student must submit his or her student's project proposal and ensure that it is proofread carefully.

questions.explanation: Option C uses singular 'his or her' matching singular antecedent 'Every student' and maintains parallel verb structure.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Based on the given data, what is the perimeter of Triangle a? (Using AAS congruence with angles 59°, 86°, 35° and sides 8, 12 on Triangle b)
questions.explanation: Using AAS congruence, corresponding sides are equal. AC = 14. Perimeter = 8 + 12 + 14 = 34.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Evaluate 3a² − 8b + 2(c − b) with a = 3, b = 4.5, c = 11

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A 4.5-pound container of gourmet coffee costs $58.95 and brews approximately 60 pots. What is the approximate cost per pot?

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What does the author emphasize by describing Katherine Johnson's early education?
questions.explanation: The text explicitly states the family's relocation decision 'underscored both sacrifices and determination to learn.'

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: In paragraph three about Katherine Johnson, 'rigor' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: Context shows mathematical work demanding 'intellectual rigor' — referring to exacting precision standards required for space calculations.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which sentence best supports the idea that Katherine Johnson helped open doors for others?

options.label: C
options.text: Her journey reveals how individual brilliance can confront and ultimately reshape systemic injustice

questions.explanation: This sentence demonstrates how her work created opportunities for future generations by reshaping systemic injustice.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Choose the correct spelling: 'The movie was [incredable/incredible] and it had a very [sensable/sensible] morale.'
questions.explanation: Both words use the '-ible' suffix: incredible and sensible.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: For Maria's paper on ocean temperature effects on global ecosystems, which source is most credible and comprehensive?

options.label: B
options.text: Peer-reviewed journal analyzing worldwide marine warming impacts

options.label: C
options.text: Scientific American article on economic effects

questions.explanation: Peer-reviewed sources provide highest academic credibility and this one directly addresses global ecosystem effects.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: 'The research team _______ three hours analyzing data before presenting findings.' Which active voice verb phrase completes it?
questions.explanation: 'Decided to spend' uses active voice (team performs the action) and maintains past tense consistency.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which coordinates represent the solution to the system: X + 3Y = 6 and 2X + Y = 7?
questions.explanation: From equation 1: X = 6 − 3Y. Substitute into equation 2: 2(6 − 3Y) + Y = 7 → 12 − 6Y + Y = 7 → Y = 1, X = 3.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Place the following numbers in order from lowest to highest: 5/6, 7/12, 0.8, 11/20, 9/4

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A jar contains 15 cookies: 6 oatmeal, 5 chocolate chip, 4 peanut butter. What is the probability of grabbing a chocolate chip cookie?
questions.explanation: P = favorable/total = 5/15 = 1/3.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Based on context, what does 'unheralded' mean in: 'yet in the 1860s, its configuration was a concept utterly unheralded'?

options.label: A
options.text: A design kept secret until patent lawsuit

options.label: B
options.text: Initially unsuccessful with no public acclaim

options.label: D
options.text: Patent not yet secured, official existence unrecognized

questions.explanation: 'Unheralded' means without prior announcement or precedent — the flat-bottomed paper bag design was completely new.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which sentence conveys the causal relationship and chronological sequence about a purloined blueprint?

options.label: A
options.text: Because individual stole blueprint, he was privy to construction...

options.label: B
options.text: Individual, who had been privy to construction, purloined blueprint and subsequently secured patent

options.label: C
options.text: After fraudulently securing patent, individual who was privy...

options.label: D
options.text: Even though individual purloined blueprint, he fraudulently secured patent only after...

questions.explanation: Option B preserves correct sequence: access → theft → fraudulent patenting, with 'subsequently' marking temporal progression.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which statement synthesizes the most significant thematic conflict and resolution in Margaret Knight's adult life?

options.label: A
options.text: Transitioned from cotton mill worker to entrepreneur founding Eastern Paper Bag Co.

options.label: B
options.text: Overcame childhood poverty through prolific inventions and patents

options.label: C
options.text: Pioneer woman who remained unmarried, established business, inducted into Hall of Fame

options.label: D
options.text: Demonstrated legal resolve and sustained ingenuity by litigating for invention rights and establishing multi-patented career

questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes her confrontation with patent theft, successful litigation, and 86 subsequent patents.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: 'Some members were selected to speak, including __________.' Which option completes this correctly?
questions.explanation: 'Including' introduces objects. Use object pronoun 'me'. Etiquette places others before self: 'my mom and me'.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which sentence demonstrates accurate punctuation?

options.label: A
options.text: Policy which, mandates weekly reports has caused friction...

options.label: B
options.text: To prepare for merger, senior team agreed to work weekend, a regrettable necessity.

options.label: C
options.text: As accomplished linguist Dr. Mansoori, understood archaic conjugations...

options.label: D
options.text: Algorithm, as you know Professor Chen is designed to calculate...

questions.explanation: Option B correctly uses comma after introductory phrase and comma before appositive phrase ('a regrettable necessity').

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Correct this misplaced modifier: 'Known for groundbreaking studies, the committee awarded Dr. Ramos the honor.'

options.label: A
options.text: Committee known for groundbreaking studies awarded Dr. Ramos...

options.label: B
options.text: Dr. Ramos, known for groundbreaking studies, was awarded honor by committee

options.label: C
options.text: Dr. Ramos, who was known for studies, was awarded honor, it was given by committee

options.label: D
options.text: Known for studies, Dr. Ramos was awarded by committee the honor

questions.explanation: The phrase 'known for groundbreaking studies' describes Dr. Ramos, so it must sit adjacent to her name.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A ball's height (in feet) after t seconds is modeled by h(t) = −16t² + 48t + 5. What is the maximum height the ball reaches?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In a right triangle with sides proportional to 3:4:5, if the hypotenuse is 25 cm, what are the other two sides?
questions.explanation: Scale factor k: 5k = 25, k = 5. Sides: 3(5) = 15 cm and 4(5) = 20 cm.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: If log₂(x − 1) + log₂(x + 1) = 3, what is x? (Domain: x > 1)
questions.explanation: Combine: log₂((x−1)(x+1)) = 3 → log₂(x²−1) = 3 → x²−1 = 8 → x² = 9 → x = ±3. Domain x > 1, so x = 3.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: In Whitman's 'When I Heard the Learn'd Astronomer', what is the effect of the word 'unaccountable' in line 5?

options.label: A
options.text: Shows speaker confused by complex data

options.label: B
options.text: Implies speaker feels guilty for leaving

options.label: C
options.text: Suggests speaker cannot logically explain emotional reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Reveals speaker unable to understand lesson

questions.explanation: 'Unaccountable' means without logical explanation. The speaker experiences an unexplainable emotional response to the analytical lecture.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What central contrast does Whitman explore in 'When I Heard the Learn'd Astronomer'?

options.label: A
options.text: Power of mathematics to explain natural beauty

options.label: B
options.text: Tension between intellectual analysis and direct personal experience

options.label: C
options.text: Importance of studying science to understand spirituality

options.label: D
options.text: Conflict between individual ambition and public recognition

questions.explanation: The poem contrasts the sterile lecture hall with scientific data against the speaker's peaceful, direct experience of nature under the stars.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: What effect does the imagery of 'the mystical moist night-air' and 'perfect silence' create at the end of the poem?

options.label: B
options.text: Reflects longing to return to lecture

options.label: D
options.text: Evokes serene, spiritual awe versus sterile lecture

questions.explanation: Sensory imagery creates a peaceful spiritual connection contrasting with the cold, analytical lecture environment.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: After thanking participants for an art workshop, Samir needs a concluding sentence. Which indicates the action he expects students to take?

options.label: A
options.text: Gallery will be shared on website and newsletter

options.label: D
options.text: Please submit project photos by Monday, April 15

questions.explanation: Only this option includes a specific action (submit), deadline, and context — functioning as a proper call-to-action.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Which sentence correctly punctuates a list with internal commas?

options.label: A
options.text: Dr. Green, the chair; Ms. Lopez, the coordinator; and Mr. Patel, the secretary

options.label: B
options.text: Dr. Green, the chair; Ms. Lopez, the coordinator, and Mr. Patel, the secretary

options.label: C
options.text: Dr. Green; the chair, Ms. Lopez; the coordinator, and Mr. Patel; the secretary

options.label: D
options.text: Dr. Green, the chair, Ms. Lopez, the coordinator; and Mr. Patel, the secretary

questions.explanation: When list items contain commas, use semicolons as separators between major items to prevent confusion.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Select the sentence that places the modifier 'only' correctly.

options.label: A
options.text: Kate said only she would finish the report Friday

options.label: B
options.text: Kate said she would finish only the report Friday

options.label: C
options.text: Only Kate said she would finish the report Friday

options.label: D
options.text: Kate said she would only finish the report Friday

questions.explanation: Placing 'only' before 'Kate' emphasizes that Kate alone made the statement. Modifier placement changes meaning.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to 9x⁴ + 21x² + 3x?
questions.explanation: Factor out 3x: 9x⁴/3x = 3x³, 21x²/3x = 7x, 3x/3x = 1. So 3x(3x³ + 7x + 1).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: For a cylinder with volume V = πr²h, what is the new volume if the radius r is tripled?
questions.explanation: V = πr²h. Tripling r: V_new = π(3r)²h = π(9r²)h = 9πr²h = 9 × V_old.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Jake's apple tree produces 50 apples monthly. Family eats 33; remaining sold at $2 each. Family eats 18 bananas monthly at $3 each. How many extra dollars beyond apple profits are needed for bananas?
questions.explanation: Apple profit: (50 − 33) × $2 = 17 × $2 = $34. Banana cost: 18 × $3 = $54. Extra needed: $54 − $34 = $20.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Based on a chart about company performance across Sales, Customer Service, and Productivity, which conclusion is best supported?

options.label: A
options.text: Customer service is the strongest area

options.label: B
options.text: Reps handle phone calls better than emails

options.label: C
options.text: Overall phone performance exceeds email performance

options.label: E
options.text: Rudeness/late arrivals/cleaning are most urgent fixes

questions.explanation: The chart data shows both positive and negative ratings for phone calls and emails, with general phone performance metrics being higher overall.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Two passages about adolescent mental health: 'Empowering Adolescents' (data-driven) and 'A Call for Change' (advocacy-focused). Which statement best captures their distinct emphasis?

options.label: B
options.text: Text 1 emphasizes early intervention effectiveness; Text 2 emphasizes systemic education integration

options.label: D
options.text: Text 1 highlights peer support; Text 2 focuses on social media

questions.explanation: Text 1 uses empirical data to showcase program success. Text 2 uses emotional testimony to advocate for structural policy reform.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which statement best reflects the differing rhetorical strategies in two texts about adolescent mental health?

options.label: A
options.text: Text 1 uses pathos; Text 2 uses ethos

options.label: B
options.text: Text 1 employs logos; Text 2 uses pathos and ethos

questions.explanation: Text 1 relies on research, facts, data (logos). Text 2 combines emotional appeal (pathos) through personal narrative and credibility (ethos) through advocacy authority.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Fill in four transition blanks in Sofia's essay on test-optional university admissions.

options.label: A
options.text: (1) Furthermore (2) In contrast (3) For instance (4) Therefore

options.label: B
options.text: (1) In contrast (2) Furthermore (3) As a result (4) However

options.label: C
options.text: (1) Furthermore (2) However (3) As a result (4) In conclusion

options.label: D
options.text: (1) For instance (2) In contrast (3) Therefore (4) Moreover

options.label: E
options.text: (1) For instance (2) On the other hand (3) As a result (4) Nevertheless

questions.explanation: (1) introduces example; (2) signals opposing view; (3) shows consequence; (4) concedes limitation while maintaining support.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Elena preparing for a speech at an auditorium. Choose between [hesitated/composed herself] and [quivered/resonated].
questions.explanation: 'Composed herself' reflects prepared confidence. 'Resonated' conveys strong, assured delivery — matching a formal, polished tone.

questions.subject: language_usage
questions.question: Adrian at a station opens a long-held letter. Which sentence best describes his emotional reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: He raised the letter slowly, paper bending between careful hands

options.label: B
options.text: His breath caught as he unfolds the letter; a tremor through his fingers despite the stillness

options.label: C
options.text: He turned the letter in his hands; the air heavy and hushed

options.label: D
options.text: His eyes drifted across the page; light glimmering over ink

questions.explanation: Option B shows involuntary physical response ('breath caught', 'tremor') — genuine emotional reaction rather than scenery or controlled actions.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Count the stars: ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ★. How many stars are there?
questions.explanation: Counting each star one by one gives us 13 stars.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: There are 15 birds sitting on a fence. 8 birds fly away. How many birds are still on the fence?
questions.explanation: 15 birds minus 8 that flew away: 15 - 8 = 7 birds are still on the fence.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which number is greater: 14 or 9?
questions.explanation: 14 is greater than 9 because 14 comes after 9 when counting.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: How many sides does a triangle have?
questions.explanation: A triangle has exactly 3 sides. The prefix 'tri' means three.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: NASA's Artemis rocket carried 7 experiments on one trip and 6 experiments on the next trip to the Moon. How many experiments were carried in total?
questions.explanation: 7 experiments + 6 experiments = 13 experiments in total.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What comes next in the pattern? Circle, Square, Circle, Square, Circle, ___
questions.explanation: The pattern alternates between Circle and Square. After Circle, the next shape is Square.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The cat is ON the table. The dog is UNDER the table. Where is the cat?
questions.explanation: The sentence says 'The cat is ON the table,' so the cat is on top of the table.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which of these does NOT belong in a group of round objects?
questions.explanation: A basketball, orange, and marble are all round. A box is not round — it has flat sides and corners.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A ball is shaped like which 3D shape?
questions.explanation: A ball is perfectly round in all directions, which is the shape of a sphere.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Put these numbers in order from smallest to largest: 18, 4, 11. Which is the correct order?
questions.explanation: From smallest to largest: 4 < 11 < 18. The correct order is 4, 11, 18.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In the number 537, what digit is in the hundreds place?
questions.explanation: In 537, the digit 5 is in the hundreds place, 3 is in the tens place, and 7 is in the ones place.

questions.subject: math
questions.explanation: 47 + 36: add the ones (7 + 6 = 13, write 3 carry 1), then the tens (4 + 3 + 1 = 8). The answer is 83.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A clock shows the hour hand on 3 and the minute hand on 6. What time is it?
questions.explanation: When the minute hand points to 6, it means 30 minutes. The hour hand on 3 means the hour is 3. So the time is 3:30.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Emma has 3 dimes and 2 nickels. How much money does she have?
questions.explanation: 3 dimes = 3 × 10 = 30 cents. 2 nickels = 2 × 5 = 10 cents. Total: 30 + 10 = 40 cents.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: There are 5 bags with 3 apples in each bag. How many apples are there in all?
questions.explanation: 5 bags × 3 apples per bag = 15 apples in all.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: NASA's Artemis team had 82 mission tasks. They completed 37 tasks in the first week. How many tasks are left?
questions.explanation: 82 - 37 = 45 tasks remaining.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A pencil is 19 centimeters long and a crayon is 12 centimeters long. How much longer is the pencil than the crayon?
questions.explanation: 19 - 12 = 7. The pencil is 7 centimeters longer than the crayon.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A bar graph shows the number of pets students have: Dogs = 8, Cats = 6, Fish = 3, Birds = 2. How many more students have dogs than fish?
questions.explanation: Dogs = 8, Fish = 3. The difference is 8 - 3 = 5 more students have dogs.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which of the following numbers is an odd number?
questions.explanation: An odd number is not evenly divisible by 2. 33 ends in 3, so it is odd. The other numbers (14, 28, 46) are all even.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Count by 5s: 45, 50, 55, 60, ___. What comes next?
questions.explanation: Counting by 5s: each number is 5 more than the previous. 60 + 5 = 65.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is 7 × 8?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A bakery made 36 cupcakes and packed them equally into 4 boxes. How many cupcakes are in each box?
questions.explanation: 36 ÷ 4 = 9 cupcakes per box.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which fraction is larger: 1/3 or 1/6?
questions.explanation: When the numerators are the same, the fraction with the smaller denominator is larger. Since 3 < 6, we have 1/3 > 1/6.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Round 467 to the nearest hundred.
questions.explanation: To round to the nearest hundred, look at the tens digit. The tens digit is 6, which is 5 or more, so round up. 467 rounds to 500.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A movie starts at 2:15 PM and ends at 4:00 PM. How long is the movie?
questions.explanation: From 2:15 PM to 4:00 PM: 2:15 to 3:15 is 1 hour, then 3:15 to 4:00 is 45 minutes. Total: 1 hour 45 minutes.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Scientists studying climate change measured a rectangular field that is 9 meters long and 4 meters wide. What is the area of the field?
questions.explanation: Area of a rectangle = length × width = 9 × 4 = 36 square meters.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A square garden has sides of 6 feet each. What is the perimeter of the garden?
questions.explanation: Perimeter of a square = 4 × side = 4 × 6 = 24 feet.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A line plot shows how many books students read in a week: 1 book (3 students), 2 books (5 students), 3 books (4 students), 4 books (2 students). How many students read exactly 2 books?
questions.explanation: According to the line plot, 5 students read exactly 2 books.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: An AI company's server room has 6 rows of computers with 9 computers in each row. How many computers are there in all?
questions.explanation: 6 rows × 9 computers per row = 54 computers in total.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Where does the fraction 3/4 fall on a number line between 0 and 1?
questions.explanation: 3/4 = 0.75, which is past the halfway point (1/2 = 0.50) and closer to 1.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is 43 × 27?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which fraction is equivalent to 3/4?
questions.explanation: Multiply both numerator and denominator of 3/4 by 2: (3×2)/(4×2) = 6/8. So 6/8 is equivalent to 3/4.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which decimal represents the fraction 7/10?
questions.explanation: 7/10 means 7 out of 10, which in decimal form is 0.7.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: An angle measures exactly 90 degrees. What type of angle is it?
questions.explanation: A right angle measures exactly 90 degrees.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The Artemis spacecraft traveled a distance of 3 kilometers to reach a testing station. How many meters is that?
questions.explanation: 1 kilometer = 1,000 meters. So 3 kilometers = 3 × 1,000 = 3,000 meters.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: How many lines of symmetry does a regular hexagon have?
questions.explanation: A regular hexagon has 6 lines of symmetry — 3 through opposite vertices and 3 through midpoints of opposite sides.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A school ordered 12 boxes of markers. Each box has 24 markers. If the markers are shared equally among 8 classrooms, how many markers does each classroom get?
questions.explanation: Total markers = 12 × 24 = 288. Divided among 8 classrooms: 288 ÷ 8 = 36 markers each.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is 756 ÷ 9?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which fraction is the largest?
questions.explanation: Convert to common denominator 40: 2/5 = 16/40, 3/8 = 15/40, 1/2 = 20/40, 3/10 = 12/40. The largest is 20/40 = 1/2.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: An AI chatbot processes requests using this pattern: 2, 6, 18, 54, ___. What comes next?
questions.explanation: Each number is multiplied by 3: 2 × 3 = 6, 6 × 3 = 18, 18 × 3 = 54, 54 × 3 = 162.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is 2/5 + 1/3?
questions.explanation: Find a common denominator: 2/5 = 6/15, 1/3 = 5/15. Then 6/15 + 5/15 = 11/15.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is 3.6 × 0.4?
questions.explanation: 36 × 4 = 144. Count decimal places: 3.6 has 1, 0.4 has 1, total 2 decimal places. So 1.44.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A rectangular box is 5 cm long, 3 cm wide, and 4 cm tall. What is the volume of the box?
questions.explanation: Volume = length × width × height = 5 × 3 × 4 = 60 cubic centimeters.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which ordered pair represents a point that is 4 units to the right and 3 units up from the origin?
questions.explanation: On a coordinate plane, the first number (x) shows right/left and the second (y) shows up/down. 4 right and 3 up is (4, 3).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the value of 8 + 3 × (10 - 4)?
questions.explanation: Using order of operations (PEMDAS): parentheses first: 10 - 4 = 6. Then multiply: 3 × 6 = 18. Then add: 8 + 18 = 26.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is 3/4 ÷ 1/2?
questions.explanation: To divide fractions, multiply by the reciprocal: 3/4 × 2/1 = 6/4 = 3/2.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: If 5n + 3 = 28, what is the value of n?
questions.explanation: 5n + 3 = 28. Subtract 3: 5n = 25. Divide by 5: n = 5.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Climate scientists recorded 12.6 inches of rain over 3 days. What was the average daily rainfall?
questions.explanation: Average = total ÷ number of days = 12.6 ÷ 3 = 4.2 inches per day.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A recipe calls for 2/3 cup of sugar. If you want to make half the recipe, how much sugar do you need?
questions.explanation: Half of 2/3 = 1/2 × 2/3 = 2/6 = 1/3 cup. Note that 2/6 simplifies to 1/3.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: An Artemis supply container for the Moon mission is 8 feet long, 5 feet wide, and 3 feet high. What is its volume?
questions.explanation: Volume = length × width × height = 8 × 5 × 3 = 120 cubic feet.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In a class, the ratio of boys to girls is 3:5. If there are 24 students in total, how many are boys?
questions.explanation: Total parts = 3 + 5 = 8. Each part = 24 ÷ 8 = 3 students. Boys = 3 × 3 = 9.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A store is having a 25% off sale. If a jacket originally costs $80, what is the sale price?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is -8 + 5?
questions.explanation: Starting at -8 on the number line and moving 5 units to the right gives -3.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Solve for x: 3x - 7 = 14
questions.explanation: 3x - 7 = 14. Add 7 to both sides: 3x = 21. Divide by 3: x = 7.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the area of a triangle with a base of 10 cm and a height of 6 cm?
questions.explanation: Area of a triangle = 1/2 × base × height = 1/2 × 10 × 6 = 30 cm².

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Find the median of this data set: 12, 7, 15, 3, 9, 20, 11
questions.explanation: First, order the data: 3, 7, 9, 11, 12, 15, 20. The middle value (4th out of 7) is 11.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: An AI system processes requests at a rate of 450 per second. At this rate, how many requests does it process in 20 seconds?
questions.explanation: 450 requests per second × 20 seconds = 9,000 requests.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A box plot shows: minimum = 10, Q1 = 15, median = 22, Q3 = 30, maximum = 40. What is the interquartile range (IQR)?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In 2025, a city's average temperature increased by 2°F. If the original average was 58°F, what is the percent increase, rounded to the nearest whole number?
questions.explanation: Percent increase = (increase ÷ original) × 100 = (2 ÷ 58) × 100 ≈ 3.4%, which rounds to 3%.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the distance between the points (2, 3) and (2, -4) on the coordinate plane?
questions.explanation: Both points have the same x-coordinate (2), so the distance is the difference in y-coordinates: |3 - (-4)| = |3 + 4| = 7.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A recipe calls for 3 cups of flour to make 24 cookies. If Maria wants to make 60 cookies for a bake sale, how many cups of flour does she need?
questions.explanation: Set up the proportion: 3/24 = x/60. Cross multiply: 24x = 180. Divide: x = 7.5 cups.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A store marks a $45 jacket down by 20%, then adds 8% sales tax to the sale price. What is the total cost?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: On a map, 1 inch represents 15 miles. Two cities are 4.5 inches apart on the map. If a car travels at 45 miles per hour, how long will the trip take?
questions.explanation: Actual distance: 4.5 × 15 = 67.5 miles. Time = distance/speed = 67.5/45 = 1.5 hours.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A bag contains 5 red, 3 blue, and 2 green marbles. If one marble is drawn at random, what is the probability that it is NOT red?
questions.explanation: Total marbles: 5 + 3 + 2 = 10. Non-red: 3 + 2 = 5. P(not red) = 5/10 = 1/2.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Solve the inequality: 3x − 7 > 14. Which value is in the solution set?
questions.explanation: 3x − 7 > 14 → 3x > 21 → x > 7. Only x = 8 satisfies x > 7.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A circular garden has a diameter of 14 meters. What is the area of the garden? (Use pi = 22/7)
questions.explanation: Radius = 14/2 = 7 m. Area = pi × r² = (22/7) × 49 = 154 m².

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A right rectangular prism is sliced with a plane that passes through it at an angle, cutting through all four lateral faces. What shape is the cross-section?
questions.explanation: An angled plane cutting through all four lateral faces of a rectangular prism creates a parallelogram cross-section.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: SpaceX's Starship booster uses 33 Raptor engines. During a 2025 test flight, 30 of the 33 engines ignited successfully. If this success rate held for a cluster of 99 engines, how many would be expected to ignite?
questions.explanation: Success rate: 30/33 = 10/11. For 99 engines: (10/11) × 99 = 90 engines.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The Starship rocket stands 121 meters tall. The previous Falcon 9 rocket stands 70 meters tall. What is the approximate percent increase in height from Falcon 9 to Starship?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A plumber charges $50 for a house call plus $35 per hour. If the total bill was $207.50, how many hours did the plumber work?
questions.explanation: Set up equation: 50 + 35h = 207.50. Subtract 50: 35h = 157.50. Divide: h = 157.50/35 = 4.5 hours.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A 13-foot ladder leans against a wall. The base of the ladder is 5 feet from the wall. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?
questions.explanation: Using Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c². So 5² + b² = 13² → 25 + b² = 169 → b² = 144 → b = 12 feet.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Triangle ABC has vertices A(1, 2), B(4, 2), and C(4, 6). If the triangle is reflected over the y-axis, what are the new coordinates of vertex B?
questions.explanation: Reflection over the y-axis negates the x-coordinate: B(4, 2) → B'(−4, 2).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A scatter plot shows hours studied vs. test scores for 20 students. The line of best fit is y = 5x + 55. Based on this model, what score would be predicted for a student who studies 6 hours?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Which of the following numbers is irrational?
questions.explanation: 0.333... = 1/3 (rational), sqrt(49) = 7 (rational), −7/4 (rational). sqrt(50) cannot be expressed as a fraction, so it is irrational.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Simplify: (2x³)⁴ / (4x²)
questions.explanation: (2x³)⁴ = 2⁴ × x¹² = 16x¹². Then 16x¹² / (4x²) = 4x¹⁰.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A cylindrical water tank has a radius of 3 feet and a height of 8 feet. What is its volume? (Use pi ≈ 3.14)

questions.subject: math
questions.question: SpaceX's Starship carries x tons of payload and the booster weighs y tons. Together they weigh 5,000 tons fully fueled. The booster weighs 3,400 tons more than the payload. What is the payload capacity (x)?
questions.explanation: Set up: x + y = 5000 and y = x + 3400. Substitute: x + (x + 3400) = 5000 → 2x = 1600 → x = 800 tons.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The Starship rocket produces approximately 7.59 × 10⁷ newtons of thrust at liftoff. Express this number in standard form.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The function f(x) = 2x − 3 represents the elevation (in thousands of feet) of a drone after x minutes. What is the elevation after 4.5 minutes?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Factor completely: 3x² − 12x − 36
questions.explanation: Factor out 3: 3(x² − 4x − 12). Find factors of −12 that add to −4: −6 and 2. So 3(x − 6)(x + 2).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Simplify: sqrt(72) + sqrt(18)
questions.explanation: sqrt(72) = sqrt(36 × 2) = 6sqrt(2). sqrt(18) = sqrt(9 × 2) = 3sqrt(2). Sum: 6sqrt(2) + 3sqrt(2) = 9sqrt(2).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Given f(x) = 2x² − 3x + 1, what is f(−2)?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: An arithmetic sequence starts at 7 and has a common difference of 4. What is the 25th term?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A phone plan charges a $25 monthly base fee plus $0.10 per text message. If a customer's bill is $43.50, how many text messages were sent?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In a right triangle, the side opposite angle A is 5 and the hypotenuse is 13. What is sin(A)?
questions.explanation: sin(A) = opposite/hypotenuse = 5/13.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In 2025, a country's GDP was $2.4 trillion, growing at 3.5% annually. Which equation models the GDP (in trillions) after t years?
questions.explanation: Exponential growth model: G(t) = initial × (1 + rate)^t = 2.4(1.035)^t. Option A is linear, not exponential.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A country's quarterly GDP growth rate (in %) over 8 quarters is modeled by r(q) = −0.5q² + 4q − 2. During which quarter does the growth rate peak?
questions.explanation: Vertex: q = −b/(2a) = −4/(2 × −0.5) = −4/(−1) = 4. The growth rate peaks in Quarter 4.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Rationalize the denominator: 6 / sqrt(3)
questions.explanation: Multiply numerator and denominator by sqrt(3): 6/sqrt(3) × sqrt(3)/sqrt(3) = 6sqrt(3)/3 = 2sqrt(3).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: If g(x) = 3x + 2, find x when g(x) = 20.
questions.explanation: Set 3x + 2 = 20. Subtract 2: 3x = 18. Divide by 3: x = 6.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Multiply: (2x + 3)(x² − x + 4)

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Simplify: (x² − 9) / (x² + 5x + 6)

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A country's population was 50 million in 2020 and grows at 1.8% per year. What is the projected population in 2030, to the nearest million?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In a circle, an inscribed angle intercepts an arc of 124°. What is the measure of the inscribed angle?
questions.explanation: An inscribed angle is half the intercepted arc: 124°/2 = 62°.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In triangle PQR, angle P = angle R. Which statement MUST be true?
questions.explanation: By the Isosceles Triangle Theorem, if two angles are equal, the sides opposite those angles are equal. Angle P is opposite QR and angle R is opposite PQ, so PQ = QR.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In a class of 30 students, 18 play sports and 12 are in band. 5 students do both. What is the probability that a randomly selected student plays sports, given that they are in band?
questions.explanation: P(Sports | Band) = P(Sports AND Band)/P(Band) = (5/30)/(12/30) = 5/12.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A country's manufacturing sector output decreases by 4% annually from its 2025 level of $800 billion. Which expression gives the output after n years?
questions.explanation: Exponential decay: multiply by (1 − rate) each year. Output = 800(1 − 0.04)^n = 800(0.96)^n.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the remainder when f(x) = x³ − 2x² + 3x − 5 is divided by (x − 2)?
questions.explanation: By the Remainder Theorem, the remainder is f(2) = 8 − 8 + 6 − 5 = 1.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The global population reached approximately 8.1 billion in 2025. If the growth rate is 0.9% per year, in approximately how many years will the population reach 9 billion? (Use log(9/8.1)/log(1.009))

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Solve for x: log₃(2x + 1) = 4
questions.explanation: Convert to exponential form: 3⁴ = 2x + 1 → 81 = 2x + 1 → 2x = 80 → x = 40.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: What is the center and radius of the circle given by x² + y² − 6x + 4y − 12 = 0?
questions.explanation: Complete the square: (x² − 6x + 9) + (y² + 4y + 4) = 12 + 9 + 4 → (x − 3)² + (y + 2)² = 25. Center (3, −2), radius = sqrt(25) = 5.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Simplify: (3 + 2i)(4 − 5i)

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In triangle ABC, a = 8, b = 11, and angle C = 60°. Find side c to the nearest tenth.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Evaluate: lim(x→3) (x² − 9)/(x − 3)

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The total compute used for AI training has been doubling every 6 months since 2020. If the compute in January 2020 was C₀, which expression gives the compute at month t?
questions.explanation: Doubling every 6 months means after t months there are t/6 doublings. Compute = C₀ × 2^(t/6).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: AI training compute doubled every 6 months from 2020, starting at C₀. How many months does it take for compute to reach 1024 × C₀?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: In triangle DEF, angle D = 45°, angle E = 75°, and side d = 10. Find side e to the nearest tenth.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Identify the conic section: 4x² + 9y² = 36
questions.explanation: Divide by 36: x²/9 + y²/4 = 1. This is the standard form of an ellipse with a² = 9 and b² = 4 (a ≠ b, so not a circle).

questions.subject: math
questions.question: If f(x) = 5x³ − 2x + 7, what is f'(x)?
questions.explanation: Apply power rule: d/dx(5x³) = 15x², d/dx(−2x) = −2, d/dx(7) = 0. So f'(x) = 15x² − 2.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A farmer has 120 meters of fencing to enclose a rectangular field. What dimensions maximize the area?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 2l + 2w = 120, so l + w = 60. Area A = l(60 − l). A'(l) = 60 − 2l = 0 → l = 30. So w = 30. Maximum area is a 30 × 30 square.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A random sample of 100 lightbulbs has a mean lifetime of 1,200 hours with a standard deviation of 80 hours. What is the 95% confidence interval for the population mean? (z* = 1.96)

questions.subject: math
questions.question: Scores on a standardized test are normally distributed with mean 500 and standard deviation 100. What percentage of students score between 400 and 600?
questions.explanation: 400 and 600 are each 1 standard deviation from the mean (z = ±1). By the empirical rule, about 68% of data falls within 1 standard deviation.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A climate scientist fits a linear regression to global average temperature anomalies (in °C) from 2000 to 2025, yielding T(y) = 0.022y − 43.6 where y is the year. What is the predicted anomaly for 2030?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A committee of 3 is to be chosen from 10 candidates. How many different committees are possible?

questions.subject: math
questions.question: The position of a particle is given by s(t) = t³ − 6t² + 9t + 2. At what time(s) is the particle at rest?
questions.explanation: Velocity v(t) = s'(t) = 3t² − 12t + 9 = 3(t² − 4t + 3) = 3(t − 1)(t − 3). Set v = 0: t = 1 and t = 3.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: A researcher collects temperature data for 10 years and calculates r² = 0.87 for a linear model. Which interpretation is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: 87% of the variation in temperature is explained by the linear relationship with year

options.label: C
options.text: 87% of the data points lie on the regression line

options.label: D
options.text: The model predicts temperature with 87% accuracy

questions.explanation: r² (coefficient of determination) represents the proportion of variance in the dependent variable explained by the independent variable.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: How many ways can the letters of the word 'LEVEL' be arranged?
questions.explanation: LEVEL has 5 letters with L repeated 2 times and E repeated 2 times. Arrangements = 5!/(2! × 2!) = 120/4 = 30.

questions.subject: math
questions.question: After a 2025 earthquake, a relief agency models supply delivery cost as C(x) = 500/x + 2x, where x is the number of trucks dispatched. How many trucks minimize cost?
questions.explanation: C'(x) = −500/x² + 2 = 0 → 500/x² = 2 → x² = 250 → x = sqrt(250) ≈ 15.81. Since x must be a whole number, x = 16 trucks.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which word begins with the same sound as 'ball'?
questions.explanation: Bear and ball both begin with the /b/ sound. The other words begin with different sounds.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the sentence: 'I can see the ___.' Which sight word best completes the sentence if there is a picture of a dog?
questions.explanation: The sight word 'dog' matches the picture and completes the sentence: 'I can see the dog.'

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Sam has a red hat. He wears it every day. He wears it to school. He wears it to the park. What is the passage mostly about?
questions.explanation: Every sentence talks about Sam and his red hat. The main idea is that Sam loves wearing his red hat.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: First, Mia woke up. Next, she brushed her teeth. Then, she ate breakfast. What did Mia do right after she woke up?
questions.explanation: The passage says 'First, Mia woke up. Next, she brushed her teeth.' So brushing teeth came right after waking up.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Tom and his sister Lily went to the pond. Lily saw a frog. She was so happy! Who saw the frog?
questions.explanation: The passage says 'Lily saw a frog.' Lily is the one who saw it.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: A book cover shows the words 'The Big Red Truck' at the top and 'By Amy Lee' at the bottom. What is the title of the book?
questions.explanation: The title of a book is the name at the top of the cover. 'The Big Red Truck' is the title. 'Amy Lee' is the author.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Emma watched the big rocket go up, up, up into the sky! She clapped her hands. 'Wow!' she said. The rocket flew so fast! What does the word 'fast' mean?
questions.explanation: Fast means quick or moving with high speed. The rocket went up very quickly.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: A picture shows a child with an umbrella and rain falling. What is the weather like in the picture?
questions.explanation: The picture shows rain falling and a child holding an umbrella, which means the weather is rainy.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Bees are very important. They fly from flower to flower. They carry pollen on their legs. This helps flowers grow into fruits and vegetables. Without bees, we would not have many of the foods we eat. What is the main idea of this passage?

options.label: B
options.text: Bees are important because they help food grow

questions.explanation: The passage explains how bees help food grow by carrying pollen. The main idea is that bees are important for food production.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Ben wanted to build a birdhouse. First, he gathered wood and nails. Next, he hammered the pieces together. Then, he painted it blue. Last, he hung it on a tree. What did Ben do right before hanging the birdhouse?
questions.explanation: The passage lists the steps in order. Right before hanging the birdhouse on a tree, Ben painted it blue.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Kai's family went to the beach. Kai built a big sandcastle. Then a wave washed it away. Kai sat down and put his head in his hands. How did Kai most likely feel when the wave washed away his sandcastle?
questions.explanation: Kai sat down and put his head in his hands after his sandcastle was destroyed. This shows he felt sad.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: A table of contents shows: Chapter 1 — Cats ... page 3, Chapter 2 — Dogs ... page 12, Chapter 3 — Birds ... page 20. On which page should you start reading to learn about dogs?
questions.explanation: The table of contents shows that the chapter about Dogs starts on page 12.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the sentence: The enormous elephant walked slowly through the forest. What does 'enormous' mean?
questions.explanation: Enormous means very large or very big. Elephants are known for being very large animals.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Leo watched a big rocket launch on TV with his dad. The rocket made a loud roar and shot up into the sky with bright flames. Leo jumped up and shouted, 'I want to be an astronaut!' Why did Leo want to be an astronaut?

options.label: A
options.text: His dad told him to be one

options.label: B
options.text: He was excited by seeing the rocket launch

options.label: C
options.text: He was scared of the loud noise

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to watch more TV

questions.explanation: Seeing the exciting rocket launch inspired Leo. He jumped up and shouted with excitement, showing the launch caused his dream.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Which sentence is an opinion?

options.label: B
options.text: Cats are the best pets ever.

options.label: D
options.text: Cats can see in the dark.

questions.explanation: An opinion is what someone believes or feels. 'Cats are the best pets ever' is a personal feeling, not a fact that can be proven.

questions.subject: reading
questions.question: Read the passage: Ava looked at the dark clouds in the sky. She grabbed her raincoat and umbrella before leaving the house. What will most likely happen next?

options.label: A
options.text: It will be a sunny day

options.label: D
options.text: Ava will stay home all day

questions.explanation: Dark clouds and bringing a raincoat and umbrella are clues that rain is coming. Ava prepared for rain.
